plants.name: Rudbeckia hirta
plants.description: A native North American wildflower known for its bright yellow petals and dark brown central cone. Often found in meadows and prairies, it attracts pollinators like bees and butterflies.
plants.funFact: Black-eyed Susans are often used in wildflower mixes to restore native habitats and support biodiversity.

plants.name: Hibiscus rosa-sinensis
plants.description: A tropical shrub with large, showy flowers that come in many colors. It blooms almost year-round in warm climates and is widely cultivated as an ornamental plant.
plants.bloomingSeason: Year-round in tropical climates; peaks in late summer and early fall
plants.location: Tropical and subtropical Asia, Hawaii, cultivated worldwide
plants.funFact: Hibiscus flowers are edible and often used to make herbal teas known as 'hibiscus tea' or 'agua de Jamaica.'

plants.name: Calluna vulgaris
plants.description: A hardy flowering shrub that covers moorlands and heathlands with tiny pink or purple bell-shaped flowers. It is well adapted to acidic soils and blooms in late summer to early fall.
plants.funFact: Heather is traditionally associated with good luck in Scotland and is an important nectar source for bees.

plants.name: Dahlia pinnata
plants.description: A tuberous-rooted plant admired for its wide variety of flower shapes and vibrant colors. It typically blooms from midsummer through fall and is popular in gardens worldwide.
plants.location: Native to Mexico and Central America, widely cultivated
plants.funFact: The dahlia is the national flower of Mexico and was originally cultivated by the Aztecs for food and ornamental use.
